block.p: When in Choreographic Doubt, Strike a Pose, or Several Poses Sally Gross, Bryan Hayes and Carolyn Lord University Settlement
When in Choreographic Doubt, Strike a Pose, or Several Poses Sally Gross, Bryan Hayes and Carolyn Lord University Settlement
The new dances Sally Gross, Bryan Hayes and Carolyn Lord presented on Friday night had strong beginnings. What most lacked were equally effective middles and ends.

One work that held attention from start to finish was "Bangles and Seeds," a suite of solos that Ms. Lord choreographed in collaboration with the performers, Rebekah Windmiller, Linda Seifert and Kari Richardson. The dancers created their own music as they moved by shaking sleigh bells and rattles that produced soft rustling and loud clacking noises. As a result, actions and sounds were always in harmony.

Ms. Lord's "Off the Wall," for the same cast, was less satisfying. The dancers began by striking poses that were followed by blackouts. When the lights brightened again, they struck new poses. And as the lights stayed on, they kept shifting positions so that they could strike even more poses. The dance looked static, but for no apparent dramatic or emotional reason.
That could also be said of Mr. Hayes's "Drastic Measures," in which Cristina Ottolini, Elke Rindfleisch and Mei-Yin Ng struck poses of their own, often with backbends and outstretched arms.

The beginning was the best part of Ms. Gross's "Divided in Thirds." Moving on and around a stool, Ms. Gross not only looked lost in thought but also appeared to be savoring fond memories, to music for wind and percussion instruments composed and played by Michael De Lia. When Ms. Gross joined Jamie Di Mare and Ms. Ng, she appeared to be someone venturing into the past to relive old times. Yet her choreographic retrospections remained vague.
